title: Lesson 1 – The Essence of Subjects
text: Subjects in Tlingit are the doers of the action| marked through evolving pronouns that shift with surrounding sounds yet preserve roots like [x̱] for I| [tu] for we| [ee] for you| [yee] for you all| and [a] for he/she/it.

title: Lesson 2 – Harmony of Sounds
text: Tlingit pronouns bend to phonetic environments| observe the contraction of [x̱a] to [x̱] in rapid speech| a hallmark of melodic adaptation.

title: Lesson 3 – Verb Pattern One
text: Study how long subject pronouns appear before verb stems: x’úx’ x̱atéew ‘I am reading’| sakwnéin x̱ax̱á ‘I am eating bread.’

title: Lesson 4 – The Power of [tu]
text: Recognize that [tu] signifies the collective ‘we’ and interacts harmoniously with stems like tootéew or toox̱á.

title: Lesson 5 – The Role of [a]
text: When the agent is he| she| or it| the verb lacks explicit marking| sometimes the placeholder [a] appears to maintain syntactic balance.

title: Lesson 6 – Interpreting Verbs
text: Analyze how each prefix carries meaning. In yéi yax̱waaḵaa tulateení| every particle reflects the web of relations.

title: Lesson 7 – Contraction
text: As verb stems extend| pronouns shorten: heen x̱adaná ‘I am drinking water’ → contracted x̱adná. Observe this rhythmic compression.

title: Lesson 8 – Verb Pattern Two
text: Long stems shorten pronouns: dleey x̱asa.ée ‘I cook meat’| dleey tusa.ée ‘We cook meat.’

title: Lesson 9 – Subjects and Stems
text: The longer the stem| the lighter the pronoun. This dance of balance ensures euphony in speech.

title: Lesson 10 – Recognizing Objects
text: Objects receive action and are identified by x̱at ‘me’| haa ‘us’| i ‘you’| yee ‘you all’| or unmarked forms for third person.

title: Lesson 11 – Verb Pattern 3A
text: x̱at isix̱án ‘You love me’| haa isix̱án ‘You love us.’ The object defines the emotional target.

title: Lesson 12 – Verb Pattern 3B
text: ix̱six̱án ‘I love you’| yee x̱six̱án ‘I love you all.’ The symmetry between subject and object enriches clarity.

title: Lesson 13 – Verb Pattern 3C
text: ax̱ tláa x̱asix̱án ‘I love my mother’| ax̱ tláa alatín ‘He watches my mother.’ Observe [a]’s dual nature.

title: Lesson 14 – The Placeholder [a]
text: [a] functions as a grammatical support beam| maintaining harmony when neither subject nor object is overtly marked.

title: Lesson 15 – Aspectual Foundations
text: Tlingit distinguishes actions by their continuity| not by time. x̱atéew means ‘I am reading’| x̱waatéew means ‘I read.’

title: Lesson 16 – Perfective Pattern
text: The prefix [w-] conveys completed action: x̱waax̱áa ‘ate’| x̱waatéew ‘read.’ Completion breathes through sound.

title: Lesson 17 – Imperfective Pattern
text: Without [w-]| verbs remain open| alive| and ongoing. x̱atéew ‘reading’ embodies continuation.

title: Lesson 18 – Comparing Aspect
text: Perfective halts movement| imperfective flows eternally. This duality defines Tlingit temporality.

title: Lesson 19 – Sound and Rhythm
text: Pronunciation patterns are rhythmic| each verb stem carries beats that guide contraction and elongation.

title: Lesson 20 – The Verb Stem
text: The stem is the heartbeat of the verb| anchoring aspect| tone| and classifier harmony.

title: Lesson 21 – Pattern One Perfective
text: x’úx’ x̱waatéew ‘I read a book’| sakwnéin x̱waax̱áa ‘I ate bread.’ Note how aspect transforms both sound and sense.

title: Lesson 22 – Pattern Two Perfective
text: heen x̱wadináa ‘I drank water’| dleey x̱wasi.ée ‘I cooked meat.’ Observe the contraction of vowel and consonant clusters.

title: Lesson 23 – Object Perfection
text: x̱at imsix̱án ‘You loved me’| haa imsix̱án ‘You loved us.’ The [im-] prefix signals completion in emotional verbs.

title: Lesson 24 – Watching Perfective
text: ix̱walitín ‘I watched you’| yee x̱walitín ‘I watched you all.’ The [wal-] cluster bridges perception and grammar.

title: Lesson 25 – Observation and Aspect
text: In perfective watching| the observer and the observed are momentarily frozen—language mirrors the event.

title: Lesson 26 – Stems and Duration
text: Short stems fit imperfective verbs| long stems govern perfective verbs. Structure follows breath.

title: Lesson 27 – Classifier Emergence
text: Classifiers stand before roots to adjust transitivity| their presence shifts meaning with surgical precision.

title: Lesson 28 – The Classifier [sh]
text: The [sh-] classifier increases action force| often marking causation or transitivity.

title: Lesson 29 – The Classifier [l]
text: The [l-] form marks reflexive or internalized action| signifying that the subject affects itself.

title: Lesson 30 – The [0] Class
text: Absence of a classifier denotes simplicity—no internal change| pure transitivity.

title: Lesson 31 – Imperfective Motion
text: Motion verbs in imperfective show ongoing travel: duwa.óon ‘he is going.’ The journey defines time.

title: Lesson 32 – Perfective Motion
text: Add [w-] for completion: duwawoó ‘he went.’ A single sound shifts the event from life to memory.

title: Lesson 33 – Negation
text: Tléil precedes verbs to negate: tléil x̱atéew ‘I am not reading.’ Melody falls slightly in negation.

title: Lesson 34 – Inquiry
text: Use [sá] for questions: Daa sá i yatee? ‘How are you?’ The rising tone marks curiosity.

title: Lesson 35 – Command
text: Imperatives omit subjects: x̱at eetí! ‘Help me!’ The listener’s role is inherently understood.

title: Lesson 36 – Conditional
text: Prefix [gu-] expresses condition: Gu-x̱waax̱áa ‘If I eat.’ Sound alone carries logical dependency.

title: Lesson 37 – Progressive
text: Insert tle for continuation: tle x̱atéew ‘still reading.’ Temporal adverbs weave verbal texture.

title: Lesson 38 – Verbal Nouns
text: Convert verbs to nouns with –x̱i or –tí: yéi jinéiyi ‘work’| x̱at eetí ‘help.’ Verbs breathe as nouns.

title: Lesson 39 – Possession
text: Use ax̱ for my| i for your| haa for our: ax̱ tláa ‘my mother’| i éesh ‘your father.’ Possession fuses into the noun.

title: Lesson 40 – Kinship
text: Kin terms precede verbs naturally: ax̱ tláa six̱án ‘I love my mother.’ Family is linguistic structure.

title: Lesson 41 – Locatives
text: Mark place with x̱án (near)| táa (inside)| kei (up). Combine with verbs for vivid direction.

title: Lesson 42 – Motion
text: Combine classifiers and locatives for motion nuance: du.óon kei ‘he went upward.’

title: Lesson 43 – Hás the Pluralizer
text: [Hás] pluralizes humans: hás x̱at six̱án ‘They love me’| ax̱ tláa hás asix̱án ‘They love my mother.’

title: Lesson 44 – Hás Placement
text: Position decides role—before verb for subject| after object for object pluralization.

title: Lesson 45 – Context and Hás
text: When multiple people exist| interpret plurality through context| not form alone.

title: Lesson 46 – Classifier Review
text: Recognize the interplay between classifier and stem| every shift rebalances voice and meaning.

title: Lesson 47 – Choosing Patterns
text: Use Pattern 1 for short stems| Pattern 2 for longer ones| classifiers often decide the form.

title: Lesson 48 – Aspectual Precision
text: Tlingit conveys texture of time| not linearity| the world moves in cycles mirrored in aspectual verbs.

title: Lesson 49 – Sound Symbolism
text: Many stems echo meaning: harsh consonants for force| soft vowels for gentleness.

title: Lesson 50 – Rhythm in Speech
text: Speech flows like song| stress often rests on the verb stem| listen for natural cadence.
